NYSSA: But we can't just leave him to...
DOCTOR: I know, Nyssa, believe me, I know, but it's hopeless. We should move. That door won't detain them for long.
THOMAS: These kens are all the same. The hearths are all drawn by the flue pipes to the same chimney. It'll be able to follow us to anywhere with a fireplace.
DOCTOR: Right, in that case, everybody upstairs, my bedroom.
NYSSA: How will that help?
DOCTOR: It doesn't have a fireplace.
THOMAS: They're here!
DOCTOR: Quick - napkins. Cover your mouth and nose. Try not to inhale, and upstairs. After me. Hurry!
THOMAS: They're right behind us.
DOCTOR: Draught excluder, against the door.
NYSSA: That won't be enough to stop them.
DOCTOR: Give me the sheets off the bed. Fasten them over the door, tight!
THOMAS: And then what? We can't stay boxed up in 'ere forever.
DOCTOR: We won't need to stay here forever. Nyssa, check the window.
NYSSA: What am I looking for? All I can see is mist.
DOCTOR: Any change in those creatures, any signs they might be dispersing.
NYSSA: Dispersing ?
DOCTOR: I've broken their link to the year 2008. Their presence here is now a paradox, which means...?
NYSSA: They originate from a future that cannot possibly exist.
DOCTOR: Exactly. And it's only a matter of time before they realise that.
THOMAS: Pair-of-docks or not, we're trapped, and none of your high-and-mighty words are going to save us.
MOTHER: [OC]: You can save them, Brewster.
THOMAS: [OC]: What?
MOTHER: [OC]: The Doctor has constructed a device. That's what's bringing the spirits here.
THOMAS: [OC]: Mother, I can barely see you.
MOTHER: [OC]: You must destroy it.
THOMAS: [OC]: But the spirits are...
MOTHER: [OC]: And then at last, I will be with you.
THOMAS: [OC]: But... but those thing'll do me in.
MOTHER: [OC]: No harm will befall you. Trust me.
THOMAS: [OC]: And the Doctor and Nyssa, I don't want them harmed.
MOTHER: [OC]: If you do as you are bid, you'll be saving their lives.
DOCTOR: Brewster, you were talking to her.
THOMAS: She told me what I had to do. She wants to help.
DOCTOR: What did she say?
THOMAS: It's you, you did it. You're the one. You brought them here.
DOCTOR: What?
THOMAS: I've got to go downstairs. I know what to do.
NYSSA: But you'll be killed.
THOMAS: Don't you worry about me, Miss.
DOCTOR: I can't allow you to do this, Brewster.
THOMAS: Out of my way, Doctor.
DOCTOR: No.
THOMAS: I said, out of my way!
NYSSA: Thomas!
THOMAS: It's Brewster, Miss. Look after him, will ya? Have to dash.
NYSSA: Doctor. Wake up, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Ow.
THOMAS: I can't do it. Mother, the... the spirits, they're everywhere.
MOTHER: [OC]: They will not attack. Proceed into the Doctor 's study.
THOMAS: Upon my soul, they're going. The spirits, they're fading away.
DOCTOR: Ah.
NYSSA: Doctor, are you all right?
DOCTOR: I'm fine. I think my pride is more bruised than anything else. That boy can certainly pack a punch.
NYSSA: He went downstairs. I couldn't stop him. Do you think he's still alive?
DOCTOR: I don't know. I wonder why he wanted to leave so urgently?
NYSSA: Doctor, the mist outside. It's clearing.
DOCTOR: It's working. They can't sustain themselves. They're becoming too unlikely to exist.
NYSSA: You mean we've defeated them? Earth's future is secure?
DOCTOR: Yes. It certainly looks like it.
THOMAS: This is it. The Doctor's machine. I still don't know about this.
MOTHER: [OC]: Now, Brewster! Destroy it. Break it, crush it, smash it to pieces.
NYSSA: And the people killed?
DOCTOR: I imagine an explanation will be found. Just another lethal London smog, all too frequent in this era.
NYSSA: Doctor, if those creatures have disappeared, then maybe Brewster might still be alive.
DOCTOR: Yes.
NYSSA: What was that?
DOCTOR: Oh no.
THOMAS: I've done it. Now, can you come back to me? Please.
MOTHER: [OC]: There is one last thing to do.
THOMAS: [OC]: What is it?
MOTHER: [OC]: The girl has an item in her possession.
NYSSA: Brewster.
THOMAS: Nyssa.
NYSSA: You're safe.
THOMAS: Oh. Sorry, Miss. Nearly knocked you over there.
DOCTOR: What happened? What have you done?
THOMAS: I've stopped them, Doctor. Stopped the spirits. Your machine was bringing them here.
DOCTOR: You idiot! This machine was all that was preventing them from actualising, and now you've wrecked it.
THOMAS: No. You had it wrong. Mother said.
DOCTOR: Listen to me, Brewster. Whatever it is inside your head telling you what to do, it isn't your mother.
THOMAS: No. She's real and true, she is.
DOCTOR: Nyssa, the window. Check outside.
NYSSA: It's clear. There's no sign of the smoke creatures. But for how long? Without the Interferometer, the time corridor will re-open.
DOCTOR: Yes, they're going to come back, and there will be no escape anywhere.
NYSSA: Then there's nothing we can do to stop them. They will have assured their own destiny, one in which they control the future of Earth.
DOCTOR: Brewster? Where's that boy gone?
NYSSA: He was here a second ago.
DOCTOR: I don't believe it. He's stolen the Tardis!

elements.text: [Part Four]
I'd done it. I smashed the Doctor's machine. Milled it good and proper. Then they came down from upstairs, the Doctor and Miss Nyssa. And Mother, she said...
[OC]: The girl has an item in her possession. There is a key in her left pocket. Take it.
So I palmed it, swift and gentle like.
Oh! Sorry, Miss. Nearly knocked you over there.
[OC]: The key will open the blue box.
Yeah! The blue box. The one out of Creek's shop. The same one I'd seen as a squeaker. And while the two of them were busy gawping the other way...
Nyssa, the window, check outside.
I took advantage. I slipped quietly behind out of sight.
There's no sign of the smoke creatures, but for how long?

It wasn't a double like any I'd seen before, but it fitted the lock snug enough, and I was inside. I found myself in this room, like a chapel, all stark and white. And there, standing at this desk thing was ... a woman, dressed all in black.
[OC]: Quickly.
Tardis doors close.
[OC]: I will guide your hands on the console.
What is this place? Where am I?
There was this noise, like engines but inside my head, hollering, and I thought I was drowning.
The Tardis dematerialises.
Doctor, without the Tardis...
We're stuck, yes. But why do it, though? Why hijack the Tardis?
Well, presumably to make sure we would be unable to escape, and could no longer disrupt the time corridor.
Yes, but Brewster never showed any interest in the Tardis.
No Doctor, he did.
What?
When he first broke in, he said he'd seen it before.
He did? Where?
He mentioned a shop. Creek's. But I don't see how this helps us now.
It means, Nyssa, that somewhere in London there is another Tardis.
Another Tardis?
Yes, or rather, my Tardis again.
You mean it is - was - in two places at once?
Precisely. Well, it is a time machine after all. But how to find one shop in the whole of London twenty years before the invention of the telephone directory.
Wait. I remember Pickens mention somewhere. Jacob's Island. That's where it is.
Right, then that's where we're going.
Haven't you forgotten something, Doctor? Those creatures. Soon they'll be all over London again.
Yes, which is why we have to leave now, while we still can.
The Tardis materialises.
Mother? Mother, are you there?

But she wasn't there no more. I was alone. I didn't know if I was dead, alive, or what I was. All I knew was there was this murderous pain in my tuppenny loaf. A throbbing like nothing I'd ever felt before.
Help me. Somebody.
The Tardis doors open.
Help me.

Then I looked out, expecting to see the old Doctor's study. It was nothing like that. It was dark, but glimmering a sort of green, and it was a city that'd fallen to rubble, burning. I could see bodies black and

charred. And everywhere , there was the fog. Those spirits streaming about, drifting through the ruins, swooping and twirling and shifting and seething. Hundreds of them, more than I could count, going on and on forever into the night.
This way. Saint Saviour's Dock.
It's nearly dawn. Doctor, look.
What?
Across the river over the city. The mist.
I see it.
It's moving through the streets, looking for us.
Then we haven't much time. Down here. Oh my word, how colourful.
Oh, the smell. I can hardly breathe.
This must be it. Jacob's Island. Careful, the wharf is slippery, and you wouldn't want to fall in.
Oh, I can't believe anyone would chose to live in such a place.
They don't, Nyssa. Poverty chooses for them. Take my hand.
Doctor, there are dead things down there .
I'd stay away from the edge, then. Anyway, we're here. Creek's second-hand goods bought and sold. Hello? Shop! Anyone in?
Doctor, the fog. It's across the river now.
Desperate times call for desperate measures. One, two!
Breaks door down.
What sort of place is this?
Quite an Old Curiosity Shop. Must have been deserted for years, judging by the build-up of dust.
Everything is decaying, even these.
Careful. (china breaks) Fortunately I don't think the last occupants left anything valuable. Except... Ah ha!
The Tardis. Doctor, those things are outside.
Yes. Well, give me the Tardis key and we'll leave. The key?
I don't have it. Brewster must have stolen it from me.
What? That's terrible news. Fortunately I always carry a spare. (Opens door.) Come on.
But how did the Tardis end up in this shop in the first place?
That's a very good question. Hopefully the answer will be in the Tardis's memory bank.
Doctor, if this Tardis comes from a point in our future...
Hmm, yes?
Then where are our future selves?
Another good question. Yes, we must be around somewhere, I imagine.
Unless something happened to us. We could be dead, couldn't we, Doctor?
You are full of good questions today, aren't you? Now that's interesting. Since the last time I was on board, the Tardis has made two journeys.
Two?
Arrived in London 1866. That was my last landing, and after that it was piloted to the year 2008 and then a return trip to the year 1833.
Those were the only two journeys?
Yes.
So the Tardis has been sitting here, waiting for us for the last thirty four years.
That would seem to be the case. Never mind, old girl, we're here now, that's the main thing.
Wait a moment. The year 2008?
Yes.
That's the year those creatures were coming from. The other end of the time corridor.
Yes, Brewster must have sent the Tardis into the version of the future those things came from.
And also the source of the psychic projection.
I wonder what happened to him?
Yes.
Only one way to find out.
The Tardis dematerialises.

I don't know how long I'd been lying there. Half-awake... weeping for my mother and my mortal soul. Then out of nowhere, there was this breeze. (the Tardis materialises) And in the middle of the floor appeared the blue box.
Tardis materialisation comes to a halt, console bleep to indicate landing, Tardis scanner operated.
I don't believe it. You've landed us in the Tardis console room.
What's wrong with that?
Doctor, landing a Tardis inside another Tardis is dangerous enough, without it being the same Tardis at an earlier point in its history.
Really? I thought it was rather neat.
The Tardis doors open.
Doctor. Miss Nyssa. Thank Heaven.
Not only have you broken into my house and destroyed a rather valuable piece of equipment, but now you've stolen my Tardis! What do you have to say for yourself?
I... I... I... I think I'm going to faint.
Doctor, he's not well.
Proximity side-effect. He's too close to the source of the psychic link. It's inducing severe neurological trauma.
So this is the Earth in the year 2008. A smouldering desolation.
Yes. Or rather, this is one of its potential futures.
The one with those creatures?
The worst of all possible worlds. They've reduced the whole planet to ash and clinker simply to generate the energy to summon this reality into existence. I think we've seen enough.
Tardis door closes.
Look after our young friend. I have to check something.
Thomas, can you hear me? Thomas?
Yes, Miss? Where am I?
What do you remember?
Mother told me to take the key off you. I didn't want to straight-up, and then I opened the box, and...
You said you'd seen the Tardis before.
The what?
The blue box, the Tardis.
Yeah. Yeah, we found it on the river, down from London Bridge. Covered in silt, it was. Creek said it must have been there for years.
Yes, thirty years at least.
How does this help us?
I need to know exactly where the Tardis ended up because that is where I'm programming it to fly to.
Of course. The second trip in the memory banks, to 1833. But if it materialises in the Thames, what will happen to us?
Well, we won't be on board, will we?
We won't?
No, we have to seal up the time corridor permanently. If I set the Tardis to travel back through the corridor, it can close the breach after it, like a... a zip fastener.
A what?

An invention from your fu... (sigh) To be honest, if you didn't understand that bit I don't think you're going to stand much of a chance with the rest. Course laid in. The Tardis will dematerialise in sixty seconds.
And we don't want to be on board?
No, we should withdraw to the Tardis.
We're in the Tardis.
The other Tardis.
Saying that, the Doctor opened up the blue box, and I stepped inside.
Tardis door closes.
Hold on. This is the same place.
Yes, but at a later point in relative time.
What?

You were in the Tardis in the year 2008, which will shortly be ending up at the bottom of the Thames. You are now inside the Tardis that was in the Thames and which is currently inside the other earlier Tardis.
Does it make sense to you?
Yes, it's quite logical.
Fair enough. Just me, then.
Now, we have to dematerialise before the other Tardis does.
The Tardis dematerialises.
You know, I'm getting quite good at this?
Doctor, it's working. The earlier Tardis is closing up the time corridor.
(muffled) And in a moment in the year 2008 those creatures won't really have existed in the past...
Help me!
(muffled) So no time corridor, no problem.
Help. My head!
(muffled) Exactly. Brewster's time...
Oh, my head. Argh!
Brewster?
Oh no. I didn't realise.
What's wrong?
Without the time corridor, the psychic link to Brewster is dying and it's taking him with it.
The link they used for the psychic projection? But that's...
JJ Old Bailey.
Yes, I can hear it too.
JJ When I grow rich.
What is it? A children's rhyme?
A psychic test signal.
JJ Say the Bells of Shoreditch.
That's how they must have tuned into his consciousness in the first place. We're landing.
I hope he'll be all right in there on his own. Well, what now?
We have to locate the point when the psychic link was first established, and find some way of preventing it.
Won't that be changing history?
Events will still unfold as before, we can't alter that, but what is killing Brewster is the fact that his past is predicated upon a future that can never come about.
A paradox.

Precisely. Brewster built a time machine to ensure the future that gave him the information to build the time machine. Remove the possibility of that future, and suddenly his life becomes a contradiction in causality.
So you need to find some way of collapsing the time paradox, resolving the contradiction.
Yes. And save a young man's life.
Well, you know I don't have the health left in me to bring up a child, what with my nerves and boys being so noisy and boisterous.
Not this one. I've never seen a less boisterous specimen.
I recognise the body. It's the same woman I saw in the Tardis.
I'm not sure if Brewster would have been invited.
He was. He mentioned to me he saw his mother laid out after she died. I think that's him.
We're too early. What year is this?
Oh no, leave the boy alone.
Got to learn she isn't coming back. Harsh reality's the only way.
Mother?
[OC]: The Doctor and Nyssa are trying to prevent me from being with you. They're attempting to reconfigure the past so you will cease to ever have known me.
Tardis door opens.
Never known you? How can that be?
Where next?
Brewster, after the funeral when did you next see your mother?
Er, I don ' t remember.
Think. Did she appear in a dream?
I don't want to lose her.
She's dead, Thomas. You've got to accept that. Stop wishing she will return. You have to let her go.
No. She's real and true.
He's clinging to her memory, trying to keep her alive, even at the expense of his own life.
Doctor, Brewster told me, after his mother died he was thrown into the spike. What's the spike?
The Tardis materialises.
Well, if you can't do for him, it'll have to be left to the parish.
You mean... the workhouse?
No more than he deserves. Miserable creature. Huh. I blame his mother...
Do you think he'll be all right?
We won't be long. A swift word with the workhouse master.
Tardis door opens.

There I was, all alone in the chapel of white, my napper pounding away and my eyes blurring with tears and then... I was somewhere else. A bridge at night, the lamp shining like angels in the mist. Though I never walked it, I knew that place all too well. It was Southwark, where my mother died.
The boy. Has he mentioned any bad dreams at all?
Bad dreams?
So, the psychic link hasn't yet been established.
I don't think so, no. We need to find the point when Brewster's mother started talking to him, guiding him rather than merely transmitting the test signal.
Tardis doors close.
Doctor, look at Thomas.
Yes. Some sort of psychic reverie.

I stood on that bridge. Could have been for minutes, could have been for hours. Then she came. My mother. Not as she'd been before - she wasn't in black. She was in housemaid's togs. She was sobbing her heart out.
Brewster.
Mother. You... you're alive.
Of course I am, my love.
But... this is before, before you...
Before I jumped.
Yes.
You can save me. I could have been with you throughout your childhood. I could have looked after you.
I can save you? How?
The Doctor and Nyssa.
What?
You must kill them.
[OC]: Ye have heard that it was said of them of old time...
No. No.
You've killed before.
[OC]: ... thou shalt not kill.
I haven't done nothing.
You allowed Creek to die. You allowed Mcintosh to die. You even caused the death of your friend Pickens.
[OC]: I'm not leaving without him!
You are a killer, Brewster.
[OC]: Thou shalt not kill.
That is who you are.
Argh! No.
No?
Thou shalt not kill. If you're my real mother, you wouldn't ask me to do such a thing.
I am your real mother!
Then I don’t want to know you. I'm better off going on without you.
You know why I did for myself, don't you? Because I had a baby that had driven me to distraction. A baby that had brought shame and ruination upon me. You, Brewster. You were the one that killed me.
No.
[OC]: Make no bones about it, Lil.
+ MOTHER: If it weren't for him...
... his blessed mother would still be here today.
You're not her. You're not her.
You'll always know. You could have saved me, but you chose not to.
Scream, splash.
Brewster, are you all right?
She's not my mother. It was all a trick, all of it. I was being used. She - it - was evil.
I'm afraid so.
I used to feel bitter. She died. Wished I could have done something. But now, I just feel sorry for her.
Brewster, you have to tell us. When did she first speak to you?
Who... who's there? What do you want?
Mister Creek, I take it.
Who's asking? Is it the Revenue? I'm only a humble river man. Ever so humble.
He claims you were working there.
I know, Doctor. I heard it all.
You heard?
When you were in the shop with Creek, I was in the back room. Not me now, but two years since.
[OC]: Filching, mm? I knew it.
It's all as it was before, like turning back the pages of a book.
When precisely was contact made? Was it while you were in the shop?
No, after I left. Me and Pickens, we mizzled Creek's boat.
So you took the boat, and then...
That's when.
Where are we going?
I don't know.
You don't know?
Away. Across the river, Limehouse, Wapping, anywhere. We'll take Creek's boat, he won't need it.
Oi, stop!
There he is. Doctor.
Thomas. Come back. You don't realise the danger you're in.
We can follow if you like, nab another boat.
Right, but Brewster, you should stay here. If you come into physical contact with your earlier self...
No way. This is my life, I'm coming with ya.
Very well.
Rowing.
Doctor, the fog. Something doesn't seem right.
Keep rowing. Keep rowing.
If we hit a boat... We can't see where we're heading.
We have to keep moving.
Doctor, there they are.
Brewster, pull us alongside.
What are we going to do?
You, stay in the boat. Whatever happens, stay in the boat.
Doctor?
And there, in Creek's boat, I could see him. Pickens, my old friend, alive again. And opposite him, there was me. Peepers wide open, frozen like in a scream.
Brewster, what is it?
And just as before, there she was, gliding over the water, serene as anything.
J2 When will that be, say the Bells of Stepney...
The woman all in black.
No! Don't do it, don't listen to her! She's not real!
Backwards scream.
Where ... what is this place?
You're in the Doctor 's house on Baker Street. Take a drink of this.
What is it?
Tea, strong and sweet.
Oh, thanks. What happened?
You called out to your earlier self. You warned him not to listen to the psychic projection masquerading as your dead mother.
Doctor. You're ‘ere too.
How are you feeling?
Fuzzy, but getting clearer. What happened after that? I don't know...
You fell in the river.
I fell in the river? And the other me, what happened to him, and Pickens?
What do you remember?
I remember us landing on the far shore, off Wapping, and Pickens waking me up.
Are you all right, Brewster? You right need looking after, you do.
What about my mother? I saw her.

By warning your earlier self, you short circuited the paradox, causing it to collapse. You convinced the projection of its own non-existence, making it aware of its own impossibility, and so it ceased to exist.
I don't get it.
I'll explain it again.
No. My head hurts enough as it is.
Your past hasn't been changed. Everything that happened to you is still part of history, but the future that you saw can now never happen. You're free.
And will I forget her? My mother?
You should get some rest.
We'll leave you.
Door closes.
You didn't answer my question. I said, will I remember her?
[OC]: Thomas?
Mother? You're here.

[OC]: You'll always remember me. But remember me as I am now, how I was before I died. Oh, I was happy when you were born. You would scarce believe it, you were my joy. My pride, my love. I wanted to be there for you, stay with you, every minute of every day, but I couldn't. I couldn't do it. I hope you'll forgive me for leaving you. Forgive me.
Mother. You're fading. Don't go.
[OC]: And remember this. I loved you, and I will always love you. You're my little baby boy. My darling.

She was gone, and I was alone, never to see her again. And I lay there, thinking. What would become of me? What did the future hold for Thomas Brewster? The Doctor and Miss Nyssa would soon be gone, and for me, it would be back to the blagging, then durance vile and the drop. A life of thieving and running and hiding. Unless I did something about it.
How is he?
He may suffer a few hallucinations, but he should make a full recovery.
The Tardis dematerialises.
Wait a moment. Has Brewster still got the key to the Tardis?
And we left him in there with it. I don't believe it. He's done it again!

THOMAS: Mother? Mother, are you there?
THOMAS: But she wasn't there no more. I was alone. I didn't know if I was dead, alive, or what I was. All I knew was there was this murderous pain in my tuppenny loaf. A throbbing like nothing I'd ever felt before.

THOMAS: charred. And everywhere , there was the fog. Those spirits streaming about, drifting through the ruins, swooping and twirling and shifting and seething. Hundreds of them, more than I could count, going on and on forever into the night.

DOCTOR: They don't, Nyssa. Poverty chooses for them. Take my hand.

DOCTOR: I'd stay away from the edge, then. Anyway, we're here. Creek's second-hand goods bought and sold. Hello? Shop! Anyone in?
